title: Paul Gascoigne suffered ‘year of hell’ before sex assault trial
text:
Paul Gascoigne who has described his sex assault accusation and trial as a “year of hell” (Picture: PA)

Former footballer Paul Gascoigne has spoken out for the first time since he was cleared of sexual assault.

The ex-England midfielder said he suffered a ‘year of hell’ after being accused of ‘forcefully’ kissing a woman on a train in August 2018.

He was found not guilty at Teesside Crown Court on Friday after he told jurors he kissed the passenger in order to give her a confidence boost when she was called a ‘fat lass’.

Gascoigne, 52, told the Sunday Mirror: ‘The last year has been a nightmare and I’ve worked hard to stay sober, in the last 6 months I’ve not touched a drop.

‘I’ve been in trouble but nothing like this.

‘I worried people would stop me going down the high street and shout abuse at me, or stop me from being around their kids.’

Paul Gascoigne leaves Teesside Crown Court with his personal manager Katie Davies (Picture: Getty)

Gascoigne said he was worried if he was convicted he would be viewed in the same way as the late billionaire Jeffrey Epstein who was accused of sex trafficking young girls.

The American killed himself in prison before he could stand trial.

Gascoigne, who suffers from alcohol addiction, said he’d taken up exercise as a replacement for drink in the past six months in order to keep himself sober and busy.

Prosecutors claimed the ex-Newcastle and Spurs footballer was drunk when he was detained on August 20 following the allegations of sexual assault.

He denied he was under the influence and claimed he was unable to drink spirits because of a special implant in his stomach that made him sick if he did.

Instead, he argued he was trying to reassure his accuser who had been called ‘fat and ugly’ by a man on a York to Newcastle train who also dismissed the idea of someone taking a photo with her.

Paul Gascoigne played 57 times for England Picture: Getty)

Gascoigne suggested his celebrity status contributed to the case being brought to court, adding: ‘I shouldn’t have to change the way I behave.

‘I’ve been kissed six times this morning – does that mean I have been sexually assaulted?’

He added there was never any sexual intention behind the kiss.

The England legend, who played 57 times for his country, was cleared of sexual assault by touching and assault by beating.
